greek.text: A beard signifies lice, not brains.
A bad dog gets the mange but he doesn’t die of it.
A bad master quarrels even with his broom.
A bad year has thirteen months.
A beard signifies lice, not brains.
A beautiful girl’s cheeks are the foes of her chastity.
A beggar never becomes a giver.
A bride has no place at her inlaws’ without the groom.
A cap sewn with pearls is not for a sore head.
A cat with gloves never catches mice.
A crow does not lay dove’s eggs.
A curse spoken is like a donkey; it always follows its master.
A different man, a different taste.
A donkey is asked to a wedding either to carry water or to bring wood.
A dove has no place amongst the crows.
A drop of wisdom is better than a sea of gold.
A drowning man takes hold of his own hair.
A fat belly did not invent gun powder.
A favor ages sooner than anything else.
A fly can drive away horses.
A fool throws a stone into the well and a thousand wise men cannot take it out.
A fox is not caught twice in the same snare.
A fox knows much; a hedgehog one great thing.
A friend is better than a thousand silver pieces.
A friend who leads one astray is an enemy.
A gift, though small, is welcome.
A goat thief came along and they put him in jail.
A good anvil is not afraid of the hammer.
A good bird begins chirping while in the egg.
A good man says no slowly; a wise man says no at once.
A good youth, a good old man.
A guest unwanted comes at meal time.
A heart that loves is always young.
A hungry bear does not perform.
A kiss must last long to be enjoyed.
A late marriage, orphaned children.
A lazy tailor finds his thread too long.
A library is a repository of medicine for the mind.
A little bait catches a large fish.
A lucky man fares better than a brave man.
A lucky person is someone who plants pebbles and harvests potatoes.
A mad bull is not to be tied up with a packthread.
A man who does not demand his rights is buried alive.
A man who throws stones at himself is not to be pitied.
A man with a skinny wife is a deceitful man.
A man without patience is like a lamp without oil.
A master speaks but few words.
A meal for the priest, a mouthful for the deacon.
A merry life ends in a poor man’s will.
A miser and a liar bargain quickly.
A miser and a liar come to terms quickly.
A miser is ever in want.
A newlywed girl takes pride in her pregnancy.
A person can be as sweet as honey or as heavy as steel.
A pitcher is taken to the fountain many times, but one time it is not.
A pomegranate never tastes like a fig.
A poor man buys what he can afford; a rich man what he wants.
A poor man who takes a rich wife has a ruler, not a wife.
A poor man with intelligence is wealthy.
A priest blesses his own bread first.
A priest does not accept another priest.
A real scoundrel turned up and they took off their hats to him.
A secret stays long in darkness but it will see the light.
A small evil may be a great good.
A society grows great when old men plant trees in whose shade they know they shall never sit.
A son-in-law never becomes a son and a daughter-in-law never quite becomes a daughter.
A starving donkey does not count the blows.
A stout bearded woman always bears something malicious.
A thousand blows on another man’s back don’t hurt.
A thousand people cannot undress a naked person.
A truth spoken before its time is dangerous.
A turning wheel does not get rusty.
A vineless vineyard and smooth-running love hold out no charm.
A well-fed man does not believe the hungry one.
A wheel doesn’t turn if it isn’t greased.
A wheel that turns gathers no rust.
A white dog is like a black dog.
A wise man would rather die than close his ears to the voice of reason.
A wolf and a sheep never agree.
A wolf is happy during a storm.
A wolf may grow old and his hair turn gray, but his mind doesn’t change to his dying day.
A wolf selects its prey from what has been accounted for.
A woman prefers a man without money to money without a man.
A word out of season may mar a whole lifetime.
A wounded horse trembles when he sees the saddle.
A young man should not marry yet, an old man not at all.
Act quickly, think slowly.
Add not fire to fire.
Advising a fool is like striking cold iron.
Affairs sleep soundly when fortune is present.
After the war, aid.
Age brings experience, and a good mind wisdom.
Alexander the Great was not very tall.
Alexander the Great wasn’t tall.
All evil deeds are repaid on earth.
All evils save death may be amended.
All receive advice. Only the wise profit from it. All receive advice.
All the old things seem beautiful, and the rich men wise.
All things good to know are difficult to learn.
An eagle’s old age is worth a sparrow’s youth.
An empty belly knows no songs.
An hour brings what a year does not.
An iron rod bends while it is hot.
An old cat likes young mice.
An old enemy never becomes a friend.
An old fox is not caught in a trap.
An open enemy is better than a false friend.
An uninvited donkey has no place at a wedding.
Any wood will do to make a signpost.
Appear always what you are and a little less.
As mother and father, so daughter and son.
Ask for advice but do what you think is best.
At the deaf man’s door, knock as much as you like.
Be thine enemy an ant, see in him an elephant.
Before you can score, you must first have a goal.
Better a drop of wisdom than an ocean of gold.
Better a light stomach than a heavy conscience.
Better a sick body than an ignorant mind.
Better a snake’s tongue to sting you than a man’s.
Better be a nobleman’s servant than a poor man’s wife.
Better brains in the head than riches and confusion.
Better cabbage and peace than dainties and fretting.
Better five coins in hand than ten in prospect.
Better luck than knowledge.
Better ten stabs than ten bad words.
Better the first of its kind than the last.
Better the friend we can see than the money we cannot.
Better to keep silent than to talk too much.
Better today’s egg than tomorrow’s chicken.
Birth, ancestry, and that which you yourself have not achieved can hardly be called your own.
But mortal bliss will never come sincere Pleasure may lead, but grief blow brings up the rear.
By labor are good things obtained.
Call no one blessed before his end.
Careless merchant, future beggar.
Careless mind, double work.
Cats and monks like fish; married women, kisses; and young girls.
Character is habit long continued.
Cherish what you have and struggle for better.
Citizens’ sins are a city’s disgrace.
Constant dripping will wear away a stone.
Curses are like chickens; they come home to roost.
Cut the thread in the middle to find an end.
Dance alone and you can jump all you wish.
Death is never at a loss for occasions.
Deeds are fruits, words are only leaves.
Do not compare a fly with an elephant.
Do not lean on a worm-eaten staff.
Do not marry your superior.
Don’t be afraid of a dog that barks.
Don’t keep any secrets of yourself from yourself.
Donkey tied, master tranquil.
Don’t be afraid of a dog that barks.
Don’t dangle by one slim hope.
Don’t hear one and judge two.
Don’t keep any secrets of yourself from yourself.
Don’t put water into somebody else’s wine.
Don’t sprout up where you have not been planted.
Don’t step even on an ant.
Don’t trouble a quiet snake.
Drop by drop the jug is filled.
Drops of water eat up stones.
Ducks always know where a lake can be found.
Each shameful deed carries with it its excuse.
Eat and drink with your relatives; do business with strangers.
Eat and drink with your relatives; do business with strangers.
Eat beans for lunch and have no friends at the dinner table.
Either dance well or quit the ballroom.
Either remain quiet, or say things that improve the silence.
Empty barrels and insignificant people always make the most noise.
Endeavor to bear the ignorance of fortune with patience.
Envy accomplishes nothing.
Even a wolf will not stay – Where sounds no bleat to offer hope of prey.
Even from a foe a man may learn wisdom.
Even from an enemy a man can learn wisdom.
Every argument has its answer.
Every country is a fatherland.
Every liar has another liar as a witness.
Every obstacle is for the best.
Every story can be told in different ways.
Every tale can be told in a different way.
Everybody wants to be somebody; nobody wants to grow.
Everyone is his own doctor.
Everything ancient is to be respected.
Everything in its proper time; even fertilizer for the cabbages.
Excess mars perfection.
Fear of the law gives safety.
Feed a wolf in the winter and he will devour you in the summer.
Fence your own vineyard, and keep your eyes from those of others.
Fire and straw do not go together.
Fire straightens a crooked bar.
First secure an independent income, then practice virtue.
Fish is not caught without a bait.
Fool me once, shame on you. Fool me twice, prepare to die.
For lazy people it is always party time.
For mortals vanished from the day’s sweet light I shed no tear rather I mourn for those who day and night live in death’s fear.
Friendship lasts as long as the pot boils.
From a broken violin do not expect fine music.
From a crow’s beak comes a crow’s voice.
From a thorn comes a rose, and from a rose comes a thorn.
From fools and children you will learn the truth.
From the lips starts the word and reaches thousands.
Gain does not give as much pleasure as loss gives grief.
Give me today and you may keep tomorrow.
God delays, but never forgets.
God gave us teeth to hold back our tongue.
God pursues sinners.
Golden coins make our crooked windows look straight.
Good accounts make good friends.
Good scales bring good customers.
Grass does not grow on stones.
Gray hair is a sign of age, not of wisdom.
Great abilities produce great vices as well as virtues.
Great birth is a very poor dish at table.
Great dangers lead to great honors.
Great talent takes time to ripen.
Greeks only agree with each other about going to the toilet.
Hand washes hand, and finger, finger.
Haste and careful work never go together.
Have a clean heart and you may walk near the altar.
He who becomes a sheep is eaten by the wolf.
He who begrudges the cat’s food finds his clothes eaten by the mice.
He who cannot bear misfortune is truly unfortunate.
He who does not esteem silver is not worthy to have silver.
He who doesn’t want to make bread sifts the flour the whole day.
He who eats and drinks with the rich leaves the table hungry.
He who finds a thing rejoices and he who owns a thing brags.
He who has a beard has a comb.
He who has been angry becomes cool again.
He who has money does what he pleases.
He who has nothing else to hold on to, will even grasp at a drawn sword.
He who has patience gets what he wants.
He who is born in jail loves jail.
He who is outside the door has already a good part of his journey behind him.
He who owns vineyards admires them and he who sees them covets them.
He who plies many trades remains without a house.
He who plunders with a little boat is a pirate; he who plunders with a fleet is a conqueror.
He who respects his parents never dies.
He who revealeth his secret maketh himself a slave.
He who seeks many things loses even a few.
He who speaks much is sure to talk nonsense.
He who strains himself grows old quickly.
He who suffers much will know much.
He who thinks the worst usually is right.
He who wants to be happy must stay at home.
He who was born in a prison remembers a prison.
He who would be happy should stay at home.
Heed not all the words of the doctor nor yet of the confessor.
Hostile and envious are the eyes of neighbors.
How you make your bed is how you are going to sleep.
Hunger is the teacher of many.
Hunger makes forts surrender.
Hunger teaches many things.
I feel pain that envy is exchanged for beautiful deeds.
I hate a jovial table companion with a good memory.
I have found it. [Eureka.]
I send thee myrrh, not that thou mayest be by it perfumed, but it perfumed by thee.
Idleness is the mother of all evil.
If advice will not improve him, neither will the rod.
If all men were just, there would be no need of valour.
If all the bees made honey, there would be enough for even gypsies to eat.
If deeds are wanting, all words appear mere vanity and emptiness.
If envy were a rash the whole village would be ill.
If it were not for hope, the heart would break.
If the baby doesn’t cry, they don’t give it the breast.
If the wind is not on your road, let it blow.
If the wolf feared rain, he would wear a cloak.
If wishes were granted, even beggars would grow rich.
If you cannot catch a fish, do not blame the sea.
If you cannot say something good, don’t say something bad.
If you haven’t spanked a little bottom, don’t threaten a big one.
If you steal something small you are a petty thief, but if you steal millions you are a gentleman of society.
If you touch a hot coal you burn yourself; a cold one, you blacken yourself.
If you wish to be good, first believe that you are bad.
Ignorance of one’s misfortunes is clear gain.
Ignorance of the law is no excuse for breaking it.
Ill beef ne’er made gude broo.
Ill-gotten gain is scattered by the devil.
Ill-timed laughter is a dangerous evil.
In baiting a mousetrap with cheese, always leave room for the mouse.
In business you need two Jews for one Greek, two Greeks for one Syrian and two Syrians for one Armenian.
In hospitality, the chief thing is the good will.
In the far off field the cabbages are fine.
In the young, silence is better than speech.
In time of drought even hail is welcome.
In times of difficulty, friendship is on trial.
Insult gives birth to insult.
It is better in times of need to have a friend rather than money.
It is better to be a soldier than a priest.
It is better to be envied than pitied.
It is better to be the best of a low family than the worst of a noble one
It is easier to talk than to hold one’s tongue.

It is not good for all our wishes to be filled; through sickness we recognize the value of health; through evil, the value of good; through hunger, the value of food; through exertion, the value of rest.
It is not what they profess but what they practice that makes them good.
It is useless to knock at the door of a deaf man.
It takes both millstones to grind the flour.
Joy and sorrow are sisters.
Keep no secrets of thyself from thyself.
Kindheartedness and honesty can be expected only from the poor.
Kindness begets kindness.
Know all and you will pardon all.
Know yourself.
Large families bring poverty.
Lazy and silly women marry well.
Learn to obey before you command.
Learn to walk before you run.
Lentils boil against their will.
Lentils without onions are like a dance without music.
Lies are the salt of truth.
Light your lamp before night overtakes you.
Like seeks like and cabbages fertilizer.
Listen to that which is well said even if it is from the mouth of an enemy.
Listen to valuable statements even if they come from your enemy’s mouth.
Live today, forget the past.
Madness does not go to the mountains, it goes to people.
Make haste slowly.
Make your bed as well as you can.
Man is the measure of all things.
Man plans many things; God alters his plans.
Many a pupil has gained more wealth than his master.
Many captains sink the ship.
Many hands at the carding but few at the dining.
Many men know how to flatter, few men know how to praise.
Many men, many minds. Many men, many minds.
Many people know how to flatter; few know how to praise.
Many pupils have gained more wealth than their masters.
Many stones will bring down the walnut.
Marriage and cooking call for forethought.
Meat is sold with bones.
Men never moan over the opportunities lost to do good, only the opportunities to be bad.
Men prone to tears are good.
Men who have lost heart never yet won a trophy.
Milk the cow, but do not pull off the udder.
Mountains are used to snow.
My donkey is dead; let no more grass grow.
My first wedding makes me proud in front of people.
Nature follows its course and a cat the mouse.
Nature has given us two ears, two eyes, and but one tongue; to the end we should hear and see more than we speak.
Needle and thread do the work well.
Neither promise wax to the saint, nor cakes to the child.
Never consult a doctor who has never been ill himself.
Never give a sword to a fool or power to an unjust man.
No mill, no meal.
No need to teach an eagle to fly.
No one loathes the smell of himself.
nor a deacon another deacon.
Not speech, but facts, convince.
Nothing in excess.
Nothing is so reckless as a blind horse.
Nothing will content him who is not content with a little.
O Strangers by Anacreon’s tomb who pass, Shed o’er it wine, in life he lov’d his glass
Observe your enemies, for they first find your faults.
Old age and poverty are wounds that can’t be healed.
Old age and treachery will overcome youth and skill.
Old men are twice children.
Old people’s words are weighed with scales.
Once you learn something it is hard to unlearn.
One cuckoo doesn’t make the spring.
One hand washes the other and both wash the face.
One has the name and another the worth.
One lights the fire, the other fans it.
One minute of patience can mean ten years of peace.
One minute of patience, ten years of peace.
One mouse eats the clothes and all the mice get into trouble.
One who goes into a mill comes out covered with flour.
One who hurries stumbles.
One who stays not before the other’s eyes is soon forgotten.
One wise man is worth more than a million fools.
One witness one liar; more witnesses, all liars.
One word spoken in anger may spoil an entire life.
Other days, other ways.
Outside a sheep, inside a wolf.
Outwardly a lamb, inwardly a wolf.
Outwardly, a doll; within, the plague.
Painless poverty is better than embittered wealth.
People’s mouths can’t be sewn up liks sacks.
Pleasure is the greatest incentive to vice.
Pleasures are transient — honors immortal.
Pleasures are transient, honors are immortal.
Poor in my youth, and in life’s later scenes – Rich to no end, I curse my natal hour, Who naught enjoyed while young, denied the means And naught when old enjoyed, denied the power
Poor men’s words have little weight.
Poverty brings nagging.
Poverty passes by an industrious man’s door.
Presence does more than the written word.
Proportion your expenses to what you have, not what you expect.
Rank does not make the man.
Receive an old man’s counsel and a learned man’s knowledge.
Remorse is worse than a beating.
Sail when the weather is fair; you do not know what the morrow will bring.
Say little and listen much.
Sharing the figs can leave you with none at all.
She who laughs not in the morning, laughs not at noon.
Sickness comes in by the bagful and goes out stitch by stitch.
Skill wins over noble birth.
Sleep is better than food.
Small children, small worries; older children, greater worries.
Some like the priest and some like the priest’s wife.
Some plant and harvest and others eat and give blessings.
Someone with an unrelenting heart is his own executioner.
Sometimes you have to throw yourself into the fire to escape from the smoke.
Son of a priest, grandson of the devil.
Sour vinegar taints the jar.
Stagnant water has an evil smell.
Stir a fire with the poker and not with your hands.
Stubbornness gets a black eye.
Success has many friends.
Success is doing what you like and making a living at it.
Success isn’t how far you got, but the distance you traveled from where you started.
Sweet is the memory of past labor.
Swift gratitude is the sweetest.
Take a young woman for the pleasure of possessing her until she is old.
Take good care of the bull if you wish him to plough well for you.
Terrifying are the weaknesses of power.
The apple will fall under the apple tree.
The beginning is half of every action
The beginning is the half of every action.
The believer is happy, the doubter is wise.
The best fish hook cannot catch limp cheese.
The best of intentions is not always enough.
The camel can’t see her own hump.
The camel does not see her own hump.
The dog does not eat hay, but he doesn’t let the donkey eat it either.
The dog survives the winter but only his skin knows how.
The donkey called the rooster big-headed.
The drowning man grips to his own hair.
The duck knows where the lake is.
The excess of a virtue is a vice.
The eye sees; the hand performs.
The eyes of the hare are not the same as the eyes of the owl.
The fiddle sings one tune and the bow another.
The first man’s steps become a bridge for the second one.
The first mistake is a lesson and teacher for those that follow.
The fly sat upon the axle of the chariot-wheel and said ‘What a lot of dust I raise!’
The fool and the clown grow old worrying over others.
The fool rejoices over his memories.
The fox that waits until the chicken falls from the perch dies from hunger.
The frog wanted to be an ox and swelled up until he burst.
The fruit of a good tree is also good.
The good skipper proves himself during a storm.
The green log is burned with the dry ones.
The grumbling mother-in-law forgets that she once was a bride.
The hard worker toiled and the lazy man rejoiced.
The heart that loves is always young.
The house of envy lies in the lowest hollows, golden, sunless, breathed upon by no wind, grim and filled full of inert chill, and lacking warmth, is always roiled in fog.
The king has many treasures but he will still take whatever you give him.
The knee is closer than the calf.
The later comer gets the bones.
The law of the city is the citizen’s honor.
The man in pain suffers while his neighbors sleep.
The man who controls his wrath conquers his foe.
The man who eavesdrops hears himself discussed.
The man who lives in a glass house does not throw stones at his neighbors.
The mill does not grind without water.
The mind of the bird is on the millet.
The miser’s riches fall into the spendthrift’s hands.
The more the mother-in-law drinks the more friendly is her greeting.
The net of the sleeper catches fish.
The old age of an eagle is better than the youth of a sparrow.
The old hen is worth forty chickens.
The only true wisdom consists in knowing that you know nothing.
The pear falls from the pear tree.
The people make the town.
The potter knows where to place the handle.
The purse of the dead man is turned inside out.
The rest of the world does not know what newlyweds know.
The rich man displays his wealth and the poor one his children.
The rich man’s wealth is enjoyed by crafty tradesmen.
The rude man shall be rudely treated.
The shepherd smells of sheep even when he becomes a nobleman.
The shoe should fit the foot and not the foot the shoe.
The sins we often regret are the sins we never commit.
The sling will burst somewhere.
The style is the man himself.
The talk of many can shake the strongest mind.
The talk of the many can cripple a man.
The thief and the liar fare well the first year.
The timid man loses many good things.
The tongue has no bones, yet it breaks bones.
The treasures turned out to be charcoal.
The unknown is ever imagined.
The unwed matchmaker looks for himself.
The whims of the living become the bequests of the dead.
The wolf doesn’t devour his prey near his den.
The world is a wheel.
The wound that a friend gives you hurts.
There is no difference between blackness and blindness.
There’s many a slip ‘twixt the cup and the lip.
They sowed the seed of an "if’ but it didn’t germinate.
They throw stones at the walnut trees, but not at the maple.
Think not on what you lack as much as on what you have.
Think with the wise, but talk with the vulgar.
Thinking evil is much the same as doing it.
Those who fight with silver spears are sure of their victory.
Time is a river of passing events — a rushing torrent.
Time is the best adviser.
Time is the soul of everything.
To deceive a diplomat speak the truth, he has no experience with it.
To have five drachmas in the hand is better than ten drachmas on paper.
To rebel in season is not to rebel.
To whom a little is not enough, nothing is enough.
Too many captains run the ship aground.
Too much talk is poverty.
Truth holds though it is bitterly taken.
Truth is not beauty, beauty is not love.
Truth lies at the bottom of a well.
Truth reigns.
Two heads don’t fit into the same cap.
Unbeaten clay cannot be made into bricks.
Under every stone sleeps a scorpion.
Unless one suffers one does not learn.
Until the crickets sing it is not summer.
Vinegar offered free is as sweet as honey.
Violent rages are soon over.
Virtue means sweat.
We became gravediggers but nobody dies anymore.
We have two ears and one mouth that we may listen the more and talk the less
We measure others with our own yardstick.
We must endure what fortune sends.
Wealth bequeathed to the children might never reach the grandchildren.
Wealth counts not so much as good will nor as knowledge and pleasant speech.
Wealth is cautious.
Welcome is the best cheer.
What becomes a habit does not change easily.
What is good to know is difficult to learn.
What is true is no more sure than the probable.
What the fox can’t reach he leaves hanging.
What you learn in youth you do not unlearn in old age.
Whatever is good to know is difficult to learn.
Whatever kind of word thou speakest, the like shalt thou bear.
Whatever the priest tells you to do, do it; what you see him do, do not.
When at a loss about how to go on, cough.
When at a loss how to go on, cough.
When God throws the dice are loaded.
When God throws the dice, they are loaded.
When the baby cries, it is either hungry or in pain.
When the crows sing the nightingales fly away.
When the devil grows old he becomes a monk.
When the devil grows poor he becomes a tax collector.
When the fox cannot reach the grapes he says they are not ripe.
When the fox grows old it becomes a nun.
When the fox is hungry he feigns sickness.
When the fox is hungry he pretends to be asleep.
When the gods are angry with a man, they give him what he asks for.
When they offer you a horse don’t look at its teeth.
When you don’t like someone you find his breath offensive.
When you go to bed with a clear head, you will not get up with a headache.
Where rage seeds, repentance reaps.
Where there is a sea there are pirates.
Where there is envy, there is meanness.
Where there is fear, there is shame.
Where there is intelligence there is knowledge.
Where there is love there is no darkness.
Where words fail beating succeeds.
Who ceases to be a friend never was one.
Who hunts two hares will catch neither.
Who wouldn’t lick his fingers when they have been dipped in honey?
Whoever feeds the wolf in the winter will be eaten by him in the spring.
Wine and children speak the truth.
Wisdom is knowing the truth, and telling it.
With money a donkey was ordained a priest.
With patience all is done.
Without a general an army is lost.
Women are as changeable as the sea.
Women have long hair and short wisdom.
Wonder is the beginning of wisdom.
Wonders will never cease.
Words can turn the course of a river.
Work done quickly gives pleasure.
You can tell a bird by its song and a man by his manner of speaking.
You can tell a lion by his claws.
You can tell who the good seamen are during a storm.
You cannot reason with a hungry belly; it has no ears.
You can’t build a wall with just one stone.
You can’t hide behind your finger.
You can’t shake hands with a clenched fist.
You easily forget the eyes that don’t see you any more.
You have to put a young girl onto an old man.
You know who the good seamen are when the storm comes.
You learn to limp if you live with cripples.
You must keep quiet or say only things that improve silence.
You will break the bow if you keep it always bent.
Young wood makes a hot fire.
Know yourself!
Well begun is half done.
Wisdom begins in wonder.
Life is short, the art long.
Wit is educated insolence.
Nature does nothing uselessly.
Wisdom outweighs any wealth.
Success is dependent on effort.
Man is the measure of all things.
The wildest colts make the best horses.
Like that of leaves is a generation of men.
Wait for the wisest of all counselors, time.
The unexamined life is not worth living.
At a touch of love, everyone becomes a poet.
Only the dead have seen the end of the war.
Better learn late, than not at all.
Many hands make light work.
Win by persuasion, not by force.
One swallow does not make a Spring.
The roots of education are bitter, but the fruit is sweet.
Let food be thy medicine and medicine be thy food.
The art of living well and the art of dying well are one.
Famous men have the whole earth as their memorial.
Those who aim at great deeds must also suffer greatly.
The art of being a slave is to rule one’s master.
An orator without judgment is a horse without a bridle.
In all things of nature, there is something of the marvellous.
Ten soldiers wisely led will beat a hundred without a head.
Education is an ornament in prosperity and a refuge in adversity.
The greater the difficulty, the more the glory in surmounting it.
Love is all we have, the only way that each can help the other.
In order to please others, we lose our hold on our life’s purpose.
Small opportunities are often the beginning of great enterprises.
One thing I know, that I know nothing. This is the source of my wisdom.
It is difficult to argue with the belly, as it has no ears.
Milk the cows that is nearby, why chase the one that runs away?
